@antinucleon updated concat just now

it's my RPN, when I run the training of classification or regression individually, there is no problem, but not when combine them together. 
As you see, my classification cost layer and regression cost layer is implemented in python.
I doubt whether something between python and mxnet has problem?
I will write these two layers in c++ manner, check whether it is ok.

@starimpact You were trying to implement these layers in python? The error you a getting is certainly coming from the fact that something went bad in the NumpyOp layer. Can you share the code for your layers? (Best as a gist)

``` python

class AnchorClassifyCost(mx.operator.NumpyOp):
    """
    Classification On Each Anchor
    """
    def __init__(self, anchor_num):
        self.mininum = 1e-32
        self.anchornum = anchor_num
        super(AnchorClassifyCost, self).__init__(True)

    def list_arguments(self):
        """
        label is 0 or 1 multi-channel matrix, 1 means positive position
        """
        return ['data', 'label', 'mark_label']

    def list_outputs(self):
        return ['output']
#        return ['output', 'predict_output']

    def infer_shape(self, in_shape):
        data_shape = in_shape[0]
        label_shape = data_shape
        mark_shape = data_shape
        output_shape = data_shape
#        predict_shape = data_shape
        return [data_shape, label_shape, mark_shape], [output_shape]
#        return [data_shape, label_shape, mark_shape], [output_shape, predict_shape]

    def forward(self, in_data, out_data):
#        return
#        print 'classify foreward'
        datain = in_data[0]
        clstag = in_data[1]
        marktag = in_data[2]
        dataout = out_data[0]
#        predictout = out_data[1]
        costmatrix = -clstag * np.log(datain + self.mininum) - (1 - clstag) * np.log(1.0 - datain + self.mininum)
        costmatrix *= marktag
        np.copyto(dataout, costmatrix)
#        np.copyto(predictout, datain)

    def backward(self, out_grad, in_data, out_data, in_grad):
#        print 'len in_grad 0:', len(in_grad), in_grad[0].shape
#        return 
#        print 'classify backward'
        datain = in_data[0]
        clstag = in_data[1]
        marktag = in_data[2]
        gdata = in_grad[0]
        gvalues = -clstag / (datain + self.mininum) + (1 - clstag) / (1.0 - datain + self.mininum)
        gvalues *= marktag
        np.copyto(gdata, gvalues)
```

@adder Is the following what you're expecting? In `mx.callback.log.train.metric`, you have use an additional argument to save the train metric.

``` r
library(mxnet)
data(BostonHousing, package="mlbench")
train.ind = seq(1, 506, 3)
train.x = data.matrix(BostonHousing[train.ind, -14])
train.y = BostonHousing[train.ind, 14]
test.x = data.matrix(BostonHousing[-train.ind, -14])
test.y = BostonHousing[-train.ind, 14]
data <- mx.symbol.Variable("data")
fc1 <- mx.symbol.FullyConnected(data, num_hidden=1)
lro <- mx.symbol.LinearRegressionOutput(fc1)
mx.set.seed(0)
err <-vector()
model <- mx.model.FeedForward.create(
  lro, X=train.x, y=train.y,
  ctx=mx.cpu(), num.round=50, array.batch.size=20,
  learning.rate=2e-6, momentum=0.9, eval.metric=mx.metric.rmse,
  batch.end.callback = mx.callback.log.train.metric(5, err))
```

So if I am not mistaken that means that nothing is holding a reference to the elements in the `info_` structure and they might get gc'd. @starimpact I will create a PR and we can see if that solves your problem.

https://docs.python.org/2/library/gc.html

```
gc.get_referrers(*objs)
Return the list of objects that directly refer to any of objs. This function will only locate those containers which support garbage collection; extension types which do refer to other objects but do not support garbage collection will not be found.
```

@adder This will be merged.

``` r
library(mxnet)
data(BostonHousing, package="mlbench")
train.ind = seq(1, 506, 3)
train.x = data.matrix(BostonHousing[train.ind, -14])
train.y = BostonHousing[train.ind, 14]
test.x = data.matrix(BostonHousing[-train.ind, -14])
test.y = BostonHousing[-train.ind, 14]
data <- mx.symbol.Variable("data")
fc1 <- mx.symbol.FullyConnected(data, num_hidden=1)
lro <- mx.symbol.LinearRegressionOutput(fc1)
mx.set.seed(0)
log <- mx.metric.logger$new()
model <- mx.model.FeedForward.create(
  lro, X=train.x, y=train.y,
  eval.data=list(
    data=test.x,
    label=test.y
  ),
  ctx=mx.cpu(), num.round=50, array.batch.size=20,
  learning.rate=2e-6, momentum=0.9, eval.metric=mx.metric.rmse,
  batch.end.callback = mx.callback.log.train.metric(5, log))
```

You need to rebuild mxnet and R package, because R package calls mxnet C++ library.

@zachmayer Actually it is quite easy to stop early. 

Just add a new callback `mx.callback.early.stop`.

It takes two arguments, `train.metric` and `eval.metric`. The training will stop once one of them goes below the standard you set.

``` r
library(mxnet)
data(BostonHousing, package="mlbench")
train.ind = seq(1, 506, 3)
train.x = data.matrix(BostonHousing[train.ind, -14])
train.y = BostonHousing[train.ind, 14]
test.x = data.matrix(BostonHousing[-train.ind, -14])
test.y = BostonHousing[-train.ind, 14]
data <- mx.symbol.Variable("data")
fc1 <- mx.symbol.FullyConnected(data, num_hidden=1)
lro <- mx.symbol.LinearRegressionOutput(fc1)
mx.set.seed(0)
model <- mx.model.FeedForward.create(
  lro, X=train.x, y=train.y,
  eval.data=list(
    data=test.x,
    label=test.y
  ),
  ctx=mx.cpu(), num.round=50, array.batch.size=20,
  learning.rate=2e-6, momentum=0.9, eval.metric=mx.metric.rmse,
  epoch.end.callback=mx.callback.early.stop(10, 10))
```

for the performance, it is "batch size / GPU" namely the batch size given to a single gpu. the number 48 is consistent with 96 shown later, because each machine has two gpus. 

the time is per epoch. i should remove the time column later

i simply fix the learning rate for the first 20 iterations, and then change it later.

The image iterator will automatically calculate/load mean file if you set mean_file="xxxxx".  see #371

Thanks, I read the source code, in train process the mean_file path is not exists, so will automatically caculate the file and save the mean.  in test process the mean_file path is exists, so will load and use the mean.

the problem is because the scheduler (root) node uses the wrong IP (127.0.0.1) which cannot be reached by others, the codes are there 

https://github.com/dmlc/ps-lite/blob/dev/tracker/tracker.py#L384
we changed `num_round` into `num_epoch`, can you please push a PR to fix it? thanks
yeah, we try to replace it by `set_optimizer`, which is probably more straightforward for optimization algorothms.  can you please push a PR to fix the example. thanks
